This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-05-30 11:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/37687). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

The Proper Human Sexual Rights and Ghanaian Family Values bill - or, more simply, the Ghanaian anti-LGBTQ bill - is a piece of Ghanian legislation which aims to introduce restrictions on LGBTQ persons, essentially making it illegal to identify as any sexual orientation other than heterosexual.

According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghanaian_anti-LGBTQ_bill#Domestic_reactions), it was introduced in June 2021:

> [Speaker of the Parliament of Ghana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaker_of_the_Parliament_of_Ghana "Speaker of the Parliament of Ghana") [Alban Bagbin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alban_Bagbin "Alban Bagbin") stated that LGBT+ rights "should not be encouraged or accepted by our society" and that "urgent actions are being taken to pass a law to eventually nip the activities of \[LGBTQ] groups in the bud."

From then on, the bill successfully went through three 'readings', as well as several committee hearings. However, then President, Nana Akufo-Addo, failed to sign the bill into law, latterly refusing to do so until two Supreme Court cases challenging the legislation were concluded.

Upon passing the Presidency to current President John Mahama, the bill expired, but the expiry was short lived, and those sponsoring the bill revived it with a renewed legal basis in light of both Supreme Court cases being [unanimously dismissed](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/crrw2r8epw8o#:~:text=Ghana's%20Supreme%20Court%20has%20unanimously,forming%20or%20funding%20LGBT%20groups.):

> A bill that would make it illegal to be anything but heterosexual in Ghana has been reintroduced in parliament with stronger backing than it got the last time lawmakers tried to get it passed into law.

> \[...]

> A parliamentary committee is expected to start its public hearings on the bill’s contents after it resumes from recess in May, said George, who’s also minister of communications in Ghana’s new cabinet.

###### Bloomberg: [Ghana Revives Anti-LGBTQ Bill in Second Attempt to Make It Law](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-04-15/ghana-revives-anti-lgbtq-bill-in-second-attempt-to-make-it-law)

**Hong Kong's top court ordered more protections for same-sex couples. Lawmakers said no.**
Hong Kong's Legislative Council rejected a government-sponsored bill in October 2025 that would have granted limited legal recognition to same-sex couples, despite a 2023 ruling by Hong Kong's top court ordering the government to establish an alternative framework for legal recognition—such as civil partnerships—by October 27, 2025. The bill, which aimed to provide rights including hospital visitation, medical record access, and organ donation decisions for same-sex couples, was opposed by 71 out of 86 lawmakers, who cited concerns over 'traditional Chinese values' and a 'lack of social consensus.' The veto marked the first major legislative split with the government since Beijing's 2021 'patriots-only' electoral reform, which eliminated pro-democracy representation. Although the Hong Kong government expressed disappointment, it stated it would respect the legislature’s decision and pursue administrative measures to protect LGBTQ rights, though details remain unclear. This rejection follows a series of progressive court rulings in 2023 and 2024, including the recognition of gender identity changes without surgery, transgender individuals’ right to use public toilets aligned with their affirmed gender, and a lesbian couple’s right to both mothers’ names on their child’s birth certificate. However, LGBTQ activism has declined, with events like Pink Dot moving online without explanation. Jimmy Sham, a leading gay rights activist and former political prisoner, called the veto a 'great pity' but urged authorities to seek consensus. Legal experts, including barrister Azan Marwah, criticized the legislature for abdicating responsibility, arguing that lawmakers should have amended the bill instead of rejecting it outright. Professor John Burns noted the government delayed action until the last moment, proposing a 'minimalist' bill. Experts warn the lack of legal protections could harm Hong Kong’s global competitiveness, particularly among multinational companies that value diversity. Advocates like law student Louis Ng emphasize that lasting change requires sustained dialogue and engagement with opponents. The Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Bureau did not respond to requests for comment.

**Ghana's Catholic Church and Protestant Council Call for Harsher Penalties for LGBTQ+ Individuals**
The Catholic Bishops' Conference and the Christian Council, a coalition of Protestant churches in Ghana, have called on parliamentarians to increase the penalties for LGBTQ+ individuals. According to Vatican News, the proposed law should be 'treated with utmost urgency.' The request, published last week, was signed by Bishop Matthew Kwasi Gyamfi, head of the Bishops' Conference, and Hilliard Dela Dogbe, head of the Christian Council. Currently, in Ghana, men who engage in 'homosexual acts' face three years in prison. A proposed law, which has been debated for years, would increase the penalty to three years' imprisonment for individuals who identify as LGBTQ+, and between five and ten years for those who 'promote' queerness. The statement from the Bishops' Conference and the Christian Council also expresses concern about the influence of foreign 'ideologies' that threaten traditional family values. However, they ignore the fact that the current ban on homosexuality was introduced by British colonial rulers in 1892, and there were no such laws before. The proposed law was already passed in 2023 but never signed by the then-President Nana Akufo-Addo due to international criticism. The Supreme Court approved the law in December 2024, but Akufo-Addo did not sign it before leaving office. The new President John Dramani Mahama has expressed support for the proposal, but wants a government bill, not a private member's bill. 'As a Christian, I represent the principle and values that there are only two sexes, man and woman, and that marriage is between man and woman,' he said. Pope Francis had previously stated that homosexuality is not a crime, but it is unclear how the new Pope Leo XIV will approach this issue. In Ghana, where the population is predominantly Christian, the rejection of LGBTQ+ individuals is almost universal, with 93% of respondents in a 2021 Afrobarometer survey saying they would not accept same-sex couples.

summary:
Across all expert perspectives, there is a clear consensus that the likelihood of Ghana signing into law the 'Proper Human Sexual Rights and Ghanaian Family Values' bill (anti-LGBTQ bill) before January 1, 2026, is high. Most experts place the probability between 75% and 92%, with only one notable outlier (African Studies/PostColonialStateTheory) estimating a much lower chance due to perceived elite division and procedural inertia.

Key factors increasing probability include:
- Overwhelming parliamentary, religious, and societal support for the bill. Survey data (Afrobarometer) show about 93% of Ghanaians oppose LGBTQ+ relationships, and public advocacy from the Christian Council, Catholic Bishops, and leading MPs is intense and urgent.
- The removal of legal obstacles: The Supreme Court has dismissed constitutional challenges, eliminating excuses for presidential or parliamentary delays.
- Recent regional trends: Burkina Faso, Uganda, and other West African countries have passed similar legislation, reducing both isolation and perceived international risk for Ghanaian policymakers.
- Presidential political incentives: Although President Mahama has expressed a preference for a government rather than a private member's bill, he is seen as unlikely to withstand such broad domestic pressure for much longer.

Factors moderating or reducing probability:
- Some procedural delays or risk of stalling remain, as Mahama could use the government/private member’s bill distinction or other technicalities to draw out the process.
- International donor and diplomatic pressure persists (e.g., threats of aid or economic sanctions), but experts mostly judge this as too weak in the current context to override domestic momentum.
- Recent political turbulence (notably, the removal of the Chief Justice) and legislative bottlenecks could slow progress, though not fundamentally block it unless actively leveraged by the president.

Experts almost unanimously agree that, barring a last-minute procedural or executive delay, the bill will likely be signed into law before the end of 2025 due to convergent elite, societal, and religious incentives. Only one perspective views entrenched elite division and procedural foot-dragging as significant enough to make passage less than 50% likely, but this is contradicted by the prevailing majority view. The weighted consensus probability, given most forecasts clustering in the 80–88% range, is very high for a "Yes" outcome.
